subject: Re: [junit] Junit and EJBs
msgSnippet: Here our some suggestions based on the way we test our EJB code. 1. Test all of the logic in the code outside of the container.  For example, your actual EJB
messageBody:
Here our some suggestions based on the way we test our EJB code.

1. Test all of the logic in the code outside of the container. For example,
your actual EJB class can delegate all of the processing to a handler, which
can be instantiated directly by the test.

2. Use the "Cactus" add-on to JUnit to write/run in-container tests that
exercise the EJB plumbing. Then you can just use HTTP for the test runner
to communicate with the EJB container, which is less of a hassle.

> java.rmi.UnmarshalException: error unmarshalling arguments;
> nested exception is:
> java.net.MalformedURLException: no protocol:

> Properties properties = new Properties();
> properties.put(Context.INITIAL_CONTEXT_FACTORY,
> "org.jnp.interfaces.NamingContextFactory");
> properties.put(Context.PROVIDER_URL,
> "file:///home/fburough/simplebean/workspace");
>
> try {
> // Get an initial context
> InitialContext jndiContext = new InitialContext(properties);
>

> Object ref = jndiContext.lookup("StringProcessor");
> StringProcessorHome home = (StringProcessorHome)
> PortableRemoteObject.narrow (ref,
StringProcessorHome.class);
> }
> The error occurs on the call to PortableRemoteObject.narrow.
>

> 1) Changed the Context.PROVIDER_URL to be "localhost:1099"
> 2) Remove the "-Djava.rmi.server.codebase=" line from the java startup
>
> The error I get then is: java.lang.ClassCastException
>
>
> Any suggestions? I hate to give up on JUnit because it works so well for

>
> Thanks,
